description:
I re-factored the derived field saving code so that all the changes were made to the base classes (StaticOutput, IOHandler, and AMRHierarchy). The only change now to the individual frontends is to rename the _read_data_set function to _read_data. This has been tested on all the different code frontends I have datasets for - Flash, Orion, Enzo, and Chombo. Since this does touch the other code frontends, it would be great if there were a way to make sure I'm not breaking anything there. 

Other points:

1. Currently, if you're working on a dataset called "fn", the code will save the field in "fn_backup.gdf", along side the "fn.yt" file. Is this dumb?

2. I did have to re-arrange the gdf writer a bit to get this to work. The code passes the test in "test_writer.py", but Casey or someone might want to make sure I'm not messing anything up in there.  

EDIT - I accidently overwrote some changes that read in periodicity information for the orion, flash, and enzo frontends. This is fixed now.
title: Saving derived fields to disk

content.raw: Wow, super cool!  I'm going to review this and get back to you.  It may be that we could also move the backup file into the base data structures, and if it's there, just use it.  What do you think?
content.html: Wow, super cool! I'm going to review this and get back to you. It may be that we could also move the backup file into the base data structures, and if it's there, just use it. What do you think?

content.raw: Two quick comments -- Which exception is this meant to catch?  If it's a particular one, we can probably either catch it, or check for the existence of the field.  (i.e., `if field in grid_group`).  The second one is, maybe this should be moved up to the base class.  I just don't quite know how we would want to do that without breaking the existing `_read_data_set` calls elsewhere.
content.html: Two quick comments -- Which exception is this meant to catch? If it's a particular one, we can probably either catch it, or check for the existence of the field. (i.e., if field in grid_group). The second one is, maybe this should be moved up to the base class. I just don't quite know how we would want to do that without breaking the existing _read_data_set calls elsewhere.

content.raw: Can we call it something a bit more descriptive that `data`?  Maybe, `saved_fields` or something?
content.html: Can we call it something a bit more descriptive that data? Maybe, saved_fields or something?

content.raw: I am +1000 on moving this up to the base class. My opinion would be that we should hold off on accepting until it is. The quick (though potentially sloppy) way to do this would mean a small refactor, as in the base class would have the method `_read_data_set`, which would then call the frontend-specific function (which would have to be named something else now), and use the backup dataset as a fallback if the field is not found in the former.
content.html: I am +1000 on moving this up to the base class. My opinion would be that we should hold off on accepting until it is. The quick (though potentially sloppy) way to do this would mean a small refactor, as in the base class would have the method _read_data_set, which would then call the frontend-specific function (which would have to be named something else now), and use the backup dataset as a fallback if the field is not found in the former.

content.raw:
Hi Matt,

I think the "data" name comes from the GDF standard, which wants fields to be stored in ``/data/grid_%010i/%(field)s``
content.html:
Hi Matt,

I think the "data" name comes from the GDF standard, which wants fields to be stored in /data/grid_%010i/%(field)s

content.raw:
Hi Matt,

On the first point, that was just a clunky way of checking whether the field was in the backup file, and I agree it should be "if field in grid_group" or something similar. 

On the second, I'm think John makes a good suggestion above.
content.html:
Hi Matt,

On the first point, that was just a clunky way of checking whether the field was in the backup file, and I agree it should be "if field in grid_group" or something similar.

On the second, I'm think John makes a good suggestion above.

Hi John,

At the moment, it doesn't, but the gdf writer does support writing out particle fields, and I think I could make it work by being slightly more sophisticated in the _read_data_set method.

content.raw:
Something odd is happening when I try this. I added a simple field:

```
#!python

def _Entropy(field, data) :
    return data["Temperature"]*data["Density"]**(-2./3.)
add_field("Entr", function=_Entropy)

```

I open a pf, then try to save the field:

```
#!python

save_field(pf, "Entr")
```

When it tries to save the field to disk, it has to get the field, so it uses the grid's "get_data" method. Since the field is composed of two fields that are actually in the file, yt calls the the I/O handler, which now bails: `KeyError: "unable to open object (Symbol table: Can't open object)"`

This was on a FLASH dataset. Funky things seem to happen when two file handles are open...
content.html:
Something odd is happening when I try this. I added a simple field:

def _Entropy(field, data) :
    return data["Temperature"]*data["Density"]**(-2./3.)
add_field("Entr", function=_Entropy)

I open a pf, then try to save the field:

save_field(pf, "Entr")

When it tries to save the field to disk, it has to get the field, so it uses the grid's "get_data" method. Since the field is composed of two fields that are actually in the file, yt calls the the I/O handler, which now bails: KeyError: "unable to open object (Symbol table: Can't open object)"

This was on a FLASH dataset. Funky things seem to happen when two file handles are open...

content.raw:
Hi John,

Thanks for testing this. It turns out that in my last update, I missed a couple of places where the grid._id_offset fix needed to be made, which ended up breaking the pull request once that fix was made to the gdf writer. 

While I was fixing that, I also found another problem with saving a field to a _backup.gdf file that already existed. That is fixed now too. The scripts [here](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3142/) and [here](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3143/) now work for me for flash, orion, chombo, and enzo datasets, after deleting any corrupted _backup.gdf files.
content.html:
Hi John,

Thanks for testing this. It turns out that in my last update, I missed a couple of places where the grid._id_offset fix needed to be made, which ended up breaking the pull request once that fix was made to the gdf writer.

While I was fixing that, I also found another problem with saving a field to a _backup.gdf file that already existed. That is fixed now too. The scripts here and here now work for me for flash, orion, chombo, and enzo datasets, after deleting any corrupted _backup.gdf files.

content.raw: So those scripts work for me now, but attempting to make a `SlicePlot` of FLASH data did not. In this case, it's because the implementation of `_read_data_slice` that the FLASH frontend has is completely independent of `_read_data`. @MatthewTurk, would rewriting `_read_data_slice` here to use `_read_data` have any undesirable side effect that you can think of?
content.html: So those scripts work for me now, but attempting to make a SlicePlot of FLASH data did not. In this case, it's because the implementation of _read_data_slice that the FLASH frontend has is completely independent of _read_data. Matthew Turk, would rewriting _read_data_slice here to use _read_data have any undesirable side effect that you can think of?

content.raw: Sorry, I think I meant to say `_read_data_set`
content.html: Sorry, I think I meant to say _read_data_set

content.raw: I'm noticing this is a potential problem for other frontends, including GDF itself.
content.html: I'm noticing this is a potential problem for other frontends, including GDF itself.

content.raw: Hi all, I hope to provide a review of this soon -- sorry I haven't yet.  @jzuhone , to quickly answer your question, I no longer believe that `_read_data_slice` is efficient, especially for large quantities of data where the amount of data skipped is small.  For FLASH it's probably faster to not use `_read_data_slice`, since what we're doing is trading the cost of constructing a (relatively expensive) python wrapper to an H5 data space versus reading the other 7 rows of data and discarding them.
content.html: Hi all, I hope to provide a review of this soon -- sorry I haven't yet. John ZuHone , to quickly answer your question, I no longer believe that _read_data_slice is efficient, especially for large quantities of data where the amount of data skipped is small. For FLASH it's probably faster to not use _read_data_slice, since what we're doing is trading the cost of constructing a (relatively expensive) python wrapper to an H5 data space versus reading the other 7 rows of data and discarding them.

content.raw: So what are we talking about here then? Removing `_read_data_slice` altogether from all frontends?
content.html: So what are we talking about here then? Removing _read_data_slice altogether from all frontends?

content.raw: I would be fine with that: it is gone in 3.0 anyway.  The only place I could see this being a big performance hit is for situations where you have a large grid that is being sliced; say, 128^3 or 512^3.  But I'm not sure.  I have to think on this.  For FLASH, `_read_data_slice` is almost certainly worse than throwing away the data that's over-read.
content.html: I would be fine with that: it is gone in 3.0 anyway. The only place I could see this being a big performance hit is for situations where you have a large grid that is being sliced; say, 128^3 or 512^3. But I'm not sure. I have to think on this. For FLASH, _read_data_slice is almost certainly worse than throwing away the data that's over-read.

content.raw: I think I'd like to see this a bit more clear: actually check and return if `data` not in the `f`, and also try for `IOError` and then return.  This would let most of the function live at top-level indentation.

content.raw:
Options moving forward:

 * Refactor `_read_data_slice` for those frontends that use it.  (Enzo, GDF, Athena, Stream.)
 * Remove `_read_data_slice`

Remove FLASH's use of `_read_data_slice`
content.html:
Options moving forward:

  • Refactor _read_data_slice for those frontends that use it. (Enzo, GDF, Athena, Stream.)
  • Remove _read_data_slice

Remove FLASH's use of _read_data_slice

content.raw: Hi Andrew, I just realized that this might end up with a medium-to-big performance regression.  Can we have it so that if `backup_filename` is `None`, we don't call `_field_in_backup`?  Otherwise we're constantly hitting the disk.  And just set `backup_filename` to `None` if it doesn't exist?
content.html: Hi Andrew, I just realized that this might end up with a medium-to-big performance regression. Can we have it so that if backup_filename is None, we don't call _field_in_backup? Otherwise we're constantly hitting the disk. And just set backup_filename to None if it doesn't exist?

content.raw:
Hi Matt,

Good point. This is fixed in the most recent update. It should now only check for the presence of a backup file once, when you load the pf.
content.html:
Hi Matt,

Good point. This is fixed in the most recent update. It should now only check for the presence of a backup file once, when you load the pf.

content.raw:
Andrew, would you mind pulling e1b7792e6807 from https://bitbucket.org/MatthewTurk/yt/ and including it in the PR?

I have removed `_read_data_slice` from most IO frontends and placed it into the base class.  I also removed the (unused) `HDF4_2D` Enzo IO handler.
